value: Advanced age (86), constitutional control over judiciary, military, IRGC, state media and Guardian Council. No major decisions occur without his consent.
notes: Single most powerful individual in Iran's factionalized autocracy

value: Ultimate authority over all branches of government. Constitutional control over judiciary, military, IRGC, state media, and half of Guardian Council.

notes: By definition loyal to Supreme Leader

value: Body of ~88 Islamic jurists constitutionally empowered to appoint or dismiss the Supreme Leader. Members elected to 8-year terms after stringent vetting. In practice acts as rubber stamp - never removed a leader.

notes: Never challenged either Supreme Leader since 1979

value: 12-member body with veto power over legislation and elections. 6 clerics appointed by Supreme Leader, 6 jurists nominated by judiciary. Vets all candidates for elected office, disqualifying those deemed insufficiently loyal.

notes: Supreme Leader effectively controls through appointments

value: High-level advisory and arbitration body. Resolves deadlocks between Majles and Guardian Council. Advises Supreme Leader on general policies. Members include senior officials from different factions.

notes: Advisory role, ultimate power rests with Supreme Leader

value: Principal defender of Islamic Republic since 1979. Answers directly to Supreme Leader, operates parallel to regular military. Central roles in internal security, strategic arsenals (ballistic missiles), commands Quds Force, sponsors allied militant groups abroad.
notes: One of the most powerful institutions in Iran
Sprawling economic empire across Iran's economy - controls construction, energy, transport, telecoms, agriculture
Ideologically committed, economically invested in regime survival

value: Paramilitary volunteer militia under IRGC command. Regime's grassroots enforcers. Integrated under IRGC control since 2007 to counter internal unrest. Deployed to quell protests and enforce social restrictions.

notes: Active members - can mobilize hundreds of thousands more
Mobilizable volunteers in times of crisis
Ideologically driven force, under IRGC command

value: Regular army tasked with defending borders and territorial integrity against external threats. Kept largely apolitical and sidelined in strategic decision-making since 1979. Role confined to conventional defense.

notes: Expected to show loyalty, but stays out of internal security/governance - wields little political influence

value: Primary civilian intelligence agency. Responsible for domestic intelligence, monitoring dissidents, counterespionage, and foreign covert operations. Works closely with IRGC intelligence units. Conducts assassinations, cyberattacks, arrests of journalists and dual nationals.
290-seat parliament. Drafts and passes legislation, can summon or impeach ministers. Legislative power constrained by Guardian Council which reviews every law. All candidates must be pre-approved.

notes: Limited to approved elites, cannot oppose Supreme Leader's directives
All major protests since 1999 were suppressed - 100% suppression rate
No meaningful concessions in any major protest
CRITICAL: Zero security force defections in 5 major protests since 1999

value: Shut-down of reformist newspaper by hardliners
Tehran University and other campuses, spread to Tabriz, Mashhad, Isfahan
Security forces stormed dormitories at night
President Khatami backed crackdown despite reformist image
Disputed June 12, 2009 re-election of President Ahmadinejad
Tehran and dozens of cities - millions marched under 'Where is my vote?' slogan

notes: No defections despite 6 months of protests

value: Basij and police used batons, tear gas, live ammunition
Green Movement leaders placed under house arrest
Economic hardship and frustration with corruption
More than 100 cities across all 31 provinces - working class/provincial areas

notes: Deadliest street unrest since the revolution

value: Cities and towns across Iran - especially working-class areas

notes: No defections despite mass lethal force

value: IRGC and anti-riot police opened fire city after city
Regime demonstrated willingness to use mass lethal force
Death of Mahsa (Jina) Amini in morality police custody after arrest for alleged improper hijab
notes: Widely believed to be from police beating
Protests persisted for months into early 2023

value: ~160 cities in all 31 provinces - led notably by young women and men

notes: No defections despite 5 months of protests

value: At least 4 demonstrators executed after rushed trials
One publicly hanged from crane as warning

notes: Hegemonic cultural group, no ethnic marginalization
Well integrated - Khamenei himself has Azeri ancestry. Separatist sentiment low.
No major insurgent group operates inside Iran
West and northwest, near Iraq/Turkey borders
Long history of rebellion since 1979. Political exclusion, cultural suppression, economic neglect, religious discrimination.
Several armed groups persist in exile in Iraqi Kurdistan
Feel economically exploited in underdeveloped region that fuels Iran's economy. Cultural marginalization.

value: ASMLA (Arab Struggle Movement for the Liberation of Ahwaz)
notes: Iran accuses of terrorist attacks (e.g. 2018 military parade)
Over 70% below poverty line. Ethnic and sectarian discrimination (Sunni). Active insurgency.
Continued low-level guerrilla attacks including cross-border raids
1979-80 uprisings suppressed with bloodshed. Relatively quiescent since.

value: Regime uses internet blackouts as primary tool during protests. Playbook: shut down or severely throttle internet, cellular data, and messaging networks to hamper protester coordination and conceal crackdown scope. Depriving protesters of communication causes scattered demonstrations to 'peter out' due to lack of mutual awareness.

National Information Network (domestic intranet) enables state to keep critical services online for government use while cutting off global internet. Centralized control through Telecommunications Company of Iran (TCI).
Can achieve near-total nationwide blackout within hours

notes: Banned since 2009, VPN circumvention is cat-and-mouse

value: Supports protests rhetorically and through sanctions on officials. Historically cautious about direct intervention. However, in severe crisis has signaled willingness to escalate: cyber weapons, sanctions tightening, even limited military strikes.
Contingency planning for kinetic action in extreme scenarios

Maximum pressure sanctions, rhetorical support for protesters. High threshold for kinetic action given risks of war. Would contemplate no-fly zones or strikes only to prevent mass atrocities or destabilizing spillover in extreme scenarios.

Views Iran as most dangerous adversary. Will not permit Iran to acquire nuclear weapons capability. Active covert operations: sabotaged nuclear facilities (Stuxnet), assassinated scientists, conducted airstrikes on nuclear sites (2025).
Hundreds of airstrikes in Syria against IRGC/Hezbollah

Red lines: (1) Iran nuclear weapons - unacceptable, met with preemptive force; (2) Advanced weapons to proxies - continual preventive strikes; (3) Direct attack on Israel - retaliation on Iranian targets. Proactive, often unilateral operations.
Strategic partner. Opposes external regime-change efforts. Provides diplomatic cover (UN veto), arms sales, some material support. But avoids entrapment in Iran's domestic turmoil.
Mild condemnation of Western strikes - no direct intervention

Politically/economically shore up Tehran, block Western intervention, encourage Iranian leaders to restore order. Opposes sudden collapse that could create chaos. Would stop short of direct military involvement inside Iran.
Strong economic ties, supports Iran as counterweight to US influence. Overriding interest is regional stability and uninterrupted energy flows. Publicly emphasizes non-interference.
Continued Iranian oil imports despite sanctions
Possible sale of cyber surveillance/crowd control tech
Opposition to UN sanctions or regime change

Safeguard economic interests and energy security, avoid entanglement, oppose US-led intervention. Would tacitly support government restoration of order. Pragmatic - would swiftly seek understanding with any new authority.
